metadata.title: Improved mechanical properties of AlSi7Mg/nano-SiCp composites fabricated by selective laser melting

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Journal of Alloys and Compounds
journal homepage: http: / /www.elsevier .com/locate/ ja lcom
Improved mechanical properties of AlSi7Mg/nano-SiCp composites fabricated by selective laser melting
Min Wang, Bo Song*, Qingsong Wei, Yusheng Shi State Key Laboratory of Materials Processing and Die & Mould Technology, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, 430074, China
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 14 April 2019 Received in revised form 16 August 2019 Accepted 17 August 2019 Available online 18 August 2019
Keywords: Selective laser melting AlSi7Mg Nano-SiC particles Improved mechanical properties
* Corresponding author. E-mail address: bosong@hust.edu.cn (B. Song).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jallcom.2019.151926 0925-8388/© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
AlSi7Mg is one of the most widely used aluminum alloys. However, its moderate strength limits its use as a structural material for critical parts. Most mechanisms used to strengthen the material sacrifice its ductility. In situ reactions during the selective laser melting (SLM) process rectify the trade-off by introducing dislocations around the subgrain boundaries and nano-twin planes in the by-product Si phase. This work was the first attempt to reinforce AlSi7Mg by nano-SiC particles fabricated by SLM. In addition, the rapid solidification rate caused solid solution strengthening, fine-grain strengthening and precipitation strengthening, which also contributed to the mechanical properties.
© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In the past few decades, because of their low density, good mechanical properties, good corrosion resistance and low cost, aluminum alloys have been widely used in many technical fields, such as the aerospace, automobile and marine industries [1e5]. However, due to the moderate strength, fatigue and wear properties of aluminum alloys, especially AlSi7Mg, these alloys are not suitable for use as structural materials for critical parts on planes or satellites. To further enhance the mechanical properties, a substantial amount of effort has been devoted to studying the modification of AlSi7Mg. The most popular method is to develop aluminum metal matrix composites (AMMC). The commonly used reinforcements for AMMCs include carbides (SiC, TiC and WC, etc.), nitride ceramics (TiN, Si3N4), oxide ceramics (Al2O3, SiO2) and other carbon allotropes, such as graphene [6,7]. Compared with the other reinforcements, TiN has a high thermal expansion, which can lead to cracks. Graphene is not only expensive but also difficult to disperse uniformly in the matrix. Al2O3 can increase the oxygen content in the molten metal, which can increase the impurity content. As a result, SiC particles are preferred because of their low density (3.21 g/cm3), high hardness, high modulus of elasticity and low cost. Among the other reinforcements, SiC particle-reinforced
AMMCs have a higher strength, higher stiffness and modulus, better corrosion resistance and wear properties.
To date, there have been many methods to fabricate SiCp reinforced aluminum alloys, such as stir casting, powder metallurgy and liquid pressing. J. Cyboro n [8] studied the structural properties of an AlSi7Mg/SiC composite produced by the stir casting method. However, all of the SiC agglomerated throughout the material volume. A. Dehghan Hamedan [9] investigated the effects of parameters of stir casting on the microstructure and mechanical properties of A356e1wt% SiC nanocomposites. The results showed that optimized parameters existed. Using the optimized processing parameters, the ultimate tensile strength and yield strength of the nanocomposite reached 173MPa and 5.38%, respectively. Sunghak Lee [10] successfully fabricated A356-SiCp composites by liquid pressing and investigated the effects of different heat treatments on the dynamic compressive properties. However, the mechanical properties were highly dependent on the matrix microstructure, distribution of the reinforcement and interface between the matrix and reinforcement [11]. The strength of the materials could be enhanced by introducing secondary phases, grain boundaries and interfaces. Unfortunately, this approach sacrifices the ductility by hindering the movement of dislocations. Particles, especially nanoparticles, tend to agglomerate due to their large surface-tovolume ratios and low wettablity. This also negatively impacts the mechanical strength. Indeed, it is a great challenge to uniformly distribute nanoparticles by casting or powder metallurgy approaches. In addition, powdermetallurgy approaches are expensive
and cannot be used to produce complex parts. Therefore, there is an urgent need to find a new method.
Selective laser melting (SLM) is a promising approach based on the layer-by-layer strategy to ptoduce complex parts from a powder [12]. It has many advantages, such as saving materials, saving time and being able to create complex components [13,14]. In recent years, only a few studies have focused on Selective laser melted AMMCs. Dongdong Gu [15e17] studied the effects of laser linear energy density on microstructure development and mechanical properties. The results showed that the densification reached 96%, and the wear resistance was enhanced. X.P. Li [18] successfully fabricated a nano-TiB2 decorated AlSi10Mg composite by SLM. The results showed a high tensile strength and excellent ductility. However, to the best knowledge of the authors, there has been no research on nano-SiC-reinforced AlSi7Mg fabricated by SLM until now.
In the present study, a nano-SiC particle-reinforced AlSi7Mg composite was first fabricated by SLM. The variations of the crystallographic phase and microstructure evolution were systematically studied. The mechanism of the improved mechanical properties was also illustrated. This research provides a novel, time-saving, low-cost approach to fabricate AlSi7Mg/nano-SiCp composites and expands the application of aluminum alloys.
Table 1 Chemical composition of the AlSi7Mg alloy (wt%).
Composition Si Mg Ti Al
Specification 6.5e7.5 0.45e0.75 0.08e0.25 Bal Powder 7.26 0.62 0.15 Bal

sections.heading: 2.1. Feedstock materials
sections.text:
The raw materials used in this research were gas atomized AlSi7Mg and nano-SiC particles. The diameter of the AlSi7Mg
Fig. 1. Particle morphology of the (a) raw AlSi7Mg powder and (c) nano-SiC/AlSi7Mg com composite.
particles was in the range of 15e53 mm and they had a spherical shape (Fig. 1a) and mean size of 35 mm (Fig. 1b). Their chemical composition is shown in Table 1. It was a little different from the AlSi7Mg used in our previous research because of the different batches [19]. The average diameter of the nano-SiC particles was 40 nm and they had a spherical shape. A nano-SiC/AlSi7Mg composite containing 2wt% nano-SiC particles was prepared by milling in an omni-directional planetary ball mill (QM-3SP4, Nanjing NanDa Instrument Plant, China) for 3 h without the balls to protect the spherical shape of the AlSi7Mg. The rotation speed was fixed at 100 rpm. After milling, the nano-SiC particles were uniformly dispersed around the surfaces of the AlSi7Mg particles (Fig. 1c). The EDS results identified the existence of nano-SiC particles because the C content increased compared with that of the raw powder (Table 2). The average size of the composite was 30.1 mm,whichwas smaller than that of the raw powder because of the addition of the nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 2.2. SLM process
sections.text:
In this study, the SLM process was performed in an EOSINT M280 powder-bed machine with a Yb fiber laser (maximum power, 370W; beam spot diameter, approx. 0.1mm; and wavelength,
posite. Particle size distribution of the (b) AlSi7Mg powder and (d) nano-SiC/AlSi7Mg
approx. 1.064 mm). Samples (length and width of 10mm, height of 5mm) were fabricated for the microstructure analysis and nanoindentation experiments. The SLM process parameters were applied as follows: the laser power and laser scanning speed were 350Wand 1200mm/s, respectively. The layer thickness was 40 mm. The hatching spacing was fixed at 0.19mm, while the scanning strategy involved rotating by 67 . The substrate was preheated to 80 C. The process parameters used for the two kinds of materials were located in their overlapped process windows. In the overlapped process windows, both of themwere free of cracks and had a good quality. For simplicity, the as-fabricated AlSi7Mg samples were named S0, and the composite samples with 2wt% nano-SiC were named S2.

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterization
sections.text: The laser reflectivity was measured using diffuse reflectance spectroscopy on an Uvevisible near infrared spectrophotometer (SolidSpec-3700, UV-2). The phase analysis of the powders and bulk samples was conducted on an XRD-7000s (Shimadzu, Japan) with a Cu tube at 40 kV and 30mA. The 2q diffraction angle varied from 20 to 90 with a step size of 10 /min. The quality of the S0 and S2 samples was determined by image process of optical micrographs. Top surfaces of the samples were mounted, grinded and polished tomirror.18 optical micrographs of each top surfaces were taken by optical microscope (OM, Olympus BX60). Based on the variation of grey-scale intensities between pores and material, the porosity was calculated by Image-Pro software. The metallographic samples were etched with Keller's reagent consisting of HCl (1.5ml), HNO3 (2.5ml), HF (1ml) and H2O (95ml). The microstructure of the samples was characterized by field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JSM-7600F, JEOL, Japan). The crystallographic orientations were analyzed by field emission scanning electron microscopy with a Sirion 200 equipped with an OMI/EBSP, and a step size of 0.8 mm was used. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Tecnai G2 F30) was utilized to analyze the internal microstructure with an operating voltage of 300 kV. It should be noted that both the EBSD and TEM were performed on the XY planes of the samples. Nanoindentation experiments were carried out on a Hysitron Triboindenter (Berkovich Indenter TI750, Hysitron, American) equipped with a diamond Berkovich tip. Before the tests, all samples were ground and polished to a mirror finish. The indentation load and hold time were fixed at 2000 mN and 2 s, respectively. Six indents were conducted on each sample, and the average value was taken. Samples for the tensile tests were manufactured on a wire electrical discharge machine. Tensile tests were conducted at room temperature with a strain rate of 1mm/ min using a Zwick Roell 020 universal testing machine without an extensometer.

sections.heading: 3.1. Microstructure characteristics
sections.text:
The porosities of S0 and S2 were calculated to be 0.59± 0.79% and 0.25± 0.11%, respectively. There are two reasons that the addition of nano-SiC can improve the density. On the one hand,
according to the laser reflectivity results, the reflectivity of AlSi7Mg and AlSi7Mg/nano-SiCp powders at wavelength 1064 nm were 31.71% and 23.05%. It can be seen that the addition of nano-SiCp reduced the laser reflectivity of the aluminum composite alloy, which indicated the increase of laser absorption. This phenomenon was also reported by other researchers [17,20e23]. This is essential for the formation of a stable molten pool that can improve the liquid-solid wettability [17]. On the other hand, small particles can fill the void of the powder bed, which helps to improve the density. The phenomenon was also been studied before [24].
Fig. 2 presents the top surface microstructures of S0 and S2 observed by SEM. Under lowmagnification, both the laser track and pores can be clearly seen on the top surfaces of S0 and S2. However, nano-SiC agglomerations can also be observed. This is because nano-SiC particles have large surface-to-volume ratios and agglomerate readily. Thematrix of both samples was Al. There were three typical zones: a fine cellular zone, coarse cellular zone and transition zone. It seems that there was no difference between S0 and S2. However, when further magnified, the difference was obvious. For example, in the fine cellular zone in Fig. 2(f), the surfaces of the Si particles condensed around the subgrain boundaries became clearer compared with the fiber-like Si shown in Fig. 2(c), and the Si particles became discontinuous. Short rod-like particles can be clearly seen under the Si particles, and they only appeared at the subgrain boundaries. Because of their nanosize and similar composition, they could not be resolved by SEM and were hard to identify. In fact, they were nanosized Al4C3, which were further identified using TEM. The presence of the Al4C3 indicated the occurrence of an in situ reaction between Al and SiC in the molten pool. The side surface of sample S2 has the same phase characteristics, as shown in Fig. 3. A schematic of the formation mechanism of different phases during the SLM process is shown in Fig. 4.
To further study the microstructure characteristics, EBSD was conducted on S0 and S2, as shown in Fig. 5. It can be found that most of the grains in Fig. 5(a) and (b) had (001), (101) and (111) crystal orientations by taking the IPF (inverse pole figure) as a reference. However, in Fig. 5(a), the areas with a red and green color look equal, which means the intensity of the (001) and (101) orientations was equal in the as-fabricated sample S0. After adding 2wt% nano-SiC particles, many small grains nucleated. As a result, the orientation was altered. The green area almost disappeared. The transition orientation, which is yellow in the orientation map in Fig. 5(b), appeared. The red area increased, which means that the intensity of the (001) orientation increased. The (001) pole figure (PF), which indicates the local crystallographic texture intensity, also identifies the transition, as shown in Fig. 6. The texture index of S0 and S2 was determined to be 5.23 and 8.87, respectively, which increased 69.60%. The grain size was substantially refined after adding the nano-SiC particles. The smallest grain sizes of S0 and S2 were 1.30 mm and 1.28 mm, respectively, and the alloy consisted of 27.1% and 44.4% of each, respectively. The average grain diameters of S0 and S2were calculated to be 4.55 mmand 3.14 mm, respectively, which were reduced by 30.99%. The reason is that large nano-SiC particles in the molten pools provided a large number of nucleation sites, which resulted in fine recrystallized grains and restricted the growth of the Al grains during the SLM process. However, the refined grains did not increase the content of highangle grain boundaries (HAGBS). In contrast, the volume fraction of the HAGBS in S0 and S2 were 22.6% and 47.2%, respectively. The volume fraction of HAGBS in S2 was almost twice as much as that in S0. The reason for this difference is the large thermal stress, contraction stress and phase transformation stress that were present during the SLM process. The large stresses led to local plastic deformation. During the process of deformation, the new grain boundaries first appeared as subgrain boundaries or low-angle
grain boundaries (LAGBS). At the same time, the previously formed LAGBS gradually evolved into HAGBS, resulting in significant grain refinement. Due to the hindrance of the precipitated phases (Si and Mg2Si) and the in situ reaction phase (Al4C3), a balance existed between LAGBS and HAGBS. The refined grains and high volume fraction of the LAGBS had a substantial effect on the mechanical properties.

sections.heading: 3.2. Phase analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 7 shows the XRD patterns obtained for a wide range of 2q (20e90 ). The initial phases in the raw AlSi7Mg powder were mainly Al and little Si. No distinct phase of Mg was found in either powder due to the low Mg content. After adding 2wt% of nano-SiC particles and milling for 3 h, the SiC phase was detected. No other new phase was found, which indicated that the SiC particles were only dispersed in the raw powders and did not react with AlSi7Mg during the milling process. For the as-fabricated S0 samples, little Mg2Si phase was detected except for Al and Si phase. This is because some Si atoms precipitated from the Al matrix and solid solution into the magnesium lattice during the rapid cooling and subsequent solidification process. This phenomenonwas also found in many other studies [1,17]. For sample S2, all of the Al, Si and Mg2Si and SiC phases were detected. There were three obvious differences. First, even though SiC can be found, the content was very low compared with the raw composite powder. It was the residual SiC. The reason is that the laser absorptivity of SiC was high because when the temperature of the molten pool exceeded 940 K, and SiC decomposed and reacted with Al according to the reaction: 4Al(l) þ 3SiC(s)/Al4C3(s) þ 3Si [25]. However, because of the rapid cooling rate of the SLM process (106 K/s), a certain amount of SiC particles did not have time to react. Second, two new peaks from the Mg2Si phase emerged at 28.08 and 40.13 , which were from (200) and (220) planes, respectively. After laser scanning, the SiC particles absorbed the laser energy and decomposed. The Si
reaction product increased the content of Si in the molten pool. More Si could solid act as solutes into the magnesium lattice to form Mg2Si. As a result, the content of Mg2Si increased. Mg2Si is a kind of reinforcement that is of great help to AleSi alloys. However, the new phase, Al4C3, which appeared at the cell boundaries, was not detected. The reason is that the content of Al4C3 was too small
and could not be resolved with XRD. Third, the diffraction intensity of the Al matrix increased compared with that of sample S0 because the orientation changed after addition of the nano-SiC particles.
To further reveal the phase characteristics, TEM was performed. In our previous work, the phases of the as-fabricated sample (S0) were studied carefully [19]. Here, we only discuss S2, as shown in
Fig. 8. The bright-field image of sample S2 is shown in Fig. 8(a) and indicates that the microstructure consisted of cell-like structures approximately 400 nm in size. Unlike S0, where Si continuously condensed around the subgrain boundaries [19], the Si networks could not be clearly observed because of the high density of dislocation lines and dislocation tangles distributed in the matrix, especially around the boundaries. Fig. 8(b) revealed that the matrix was still Al. However, stacking faults can be found in the matrix. Because the phases precipitated around the cell boundaries were on the nanoscale, a high density of dislocations made it difficult to distinguish. Thus, HRTEM was performed. Along the cell boundaries, the high-resolution crystal lattice of Si, Mg2Si and the short rod-like Al4C3 particles were found as shown in Fig. 8(c), (d) and (h), respectively. From the HRTEM results, it had a good interface between Al/Si. The interface between Al and residual SiC was not very good compared with that of Al/Si. Al4C3 is a hard phase (250 HV) [16]. However, Unlike the Al4C3 presented in other works [26e28],
the Al4C3 in situ reaction phase that occurred during the SLM process was on the nanoscale. It had been reported that Al4C3 was a double-edged sword. A certain amount Al4C3 have positive effects for the wettability of aluminum alloy and SiC [29]. What's more, it produced effective precipitation enhancement. In addition, the byproduct Si produced by in situ reaction had several nanoscale twin planes, as shown in Fig. 8(g). A twin boundary is a special lowenergy coherent boundary that can effectively hinder dislocation movement and strengthens the material. With a decrease in the thickness of the twin, the number of dislocations in the twin decreased gradually, and the external stress required for dislocations to cross the turbulent boundary increased. When the twin layer is so thin that obstruction from the dislocations cannot be realized, a very high external stress is required to force a single dislocation to cross the twin [30]. This phenomenon has a substantial impact on the mechanical properties.

sections.heading: 3.3.1. Study of nanohardness
sections.text: To understand the influence of nano-SiC particles on the hardness of the composites, nanoindentation tests were performed on the top surfaces of samples S0 and S2. The load-displacement results are shown in Fig. 9. The average indentation depth of S0 was 205.15± 3.42 nm. After adding 2% nano-SiC particles, the average indentation depth decreased to 191.37± 9.72 nm, which indicated that S2 was able to resist deformation better than sample S0. The nanohardnesses (H) of S0 and S2 were 1.85± 0.06 GPa and 2.11± 0.2 GPa, respectively, while the Young's moduli (G) were 86.45± 1.74 GPa and 94.53± 5.10 GPa, respectively. The H and G values increased with the addition of nano-SiC particles. This phenomenon can be mainly attributed to three factors: (i) according to the XRD result, the content of the precipitated phases (Si and Mg2Si) increased and nano-Al4C3 formed because of the in situ reaction, which led to a precipitation strengthening effect; (ii) according to the TEM results, nano twin planes of by-product Si produced by in situ reaction can effectively hinder themovement of dislocations, which substantially decrease the deformation and improve the hardness; and (iii) according to the EBSD results, grain refinement can also contribute to the hardness. In addition, the error bar for sample S0 was smaller than that for S2, which indicated that the microstructure of sample S0 was more uniform than that of S2.

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Tensile properties
sections.text:
Fig. 10 shows the room temperature tensile results. The tensile stress and strain for S0 were 388.31± 49.60MPa and 7.03± 1.25%, respectively. After adding 2% nano-SiC particles, the tensile stress and strain for S2 increased to 502.94MPa and 10.64± 1.06%, respectively. This phenomenon is very important because the tensile stress increased greatly without sacrificing the elongation property. On the one hand, the fine-grain strengthening, precipitation strengthening, solid solution strengthening as well as the nano twin planes would make a great contribution to the strength. On the other hand, the dislocations around the subgrain boundaries would be an ideal “modulator” during plastic deformation because they can maintain the configuration by slowing down but not entirely blocking the dislocation motion. As a result, both the tensile strength and elongation increased.
To investigate the mechanism for the evolution of the tensile properties, the fracture surfaces of S0 and S2 are shown in Fig. 11. The fracture surfaces of S0 and S2 were irregular, as shown in Fig. 11(a) and (d), respectively. Unmelted powders, cavities and pores can be clearly observed. These were the weak areas during the tensile tests. The magnified fracture surfaces of S0 showed a
predominant cleavage river pattern, which represented the crack propagation paths. Upon further magnification of the fracture surface of S0, many dimples can be seen. This indicated that the fracture mechanism of S0 was mixed fracture. Along the dimples’ boundaries, broken Si particles can be found. It has been reported
that the fracture strain was dependent on the critical amount of damage by Si particle craking [1]. In contrast to the fracture of S0, the fracture of S2 showed more cleavage facets. However, when further magnifying the core of the cleavage facets, many elongated dimples can be clearly observed. This indicated that sample S2
experienced a large plastic deformation before cracking, which resulted in a high strain. The reasons contributed to the high strength and high ductility can be concluded as following: first, after adding nano-SiCp, there were dislocations around the cell boundaries. They could hinder the dislocation motion and increased dislocation storage, which resulted in a high strength. second, the solid solution mechanism and particles such as Si,
Mg2Si and nano-precipitated Al4C3 around the cell boundaries also increased the strength. Third, with an increase in the stress, the impeded dislocations moved through the dislocation networks. At the same time, the pinning effect from the particles around the cell boundaries effectively stabilized the dislocation networks, resulting in stable plastic flow [31]. Moreover, the low-angle misorientation between dislocation cells can also stabilize the dislocation
networks. The stability of the dislocation networks was essential to the high ductility. At last, grain refinement effect can increase the strength and strain at the same time. However, at high magnification Fig. 11(f), dimples of S2 were not completed. It seemed that they were broken at the region of Si and Al4C3. Debonding of Al/Si and Al/Al4C3 can be clearly observed, which identified that the strain was out of the endurance of the particles. Because nano-SiCp was too small and had nearly reacted completely, it can hardly found the debonding of Al/SiC.

sections.heading: 4. Summary
sections.text:
In this work, AlSi7Mg/nano-SiCp composites were fabricated by selective laser melting (SLM). Compared with AlSi7Mg (S0) without the addition of nano-SiC particles, the advantageousmicrostructure and mechanical properties of S2 are presented. At the same time, the mechanical strengthening mechanism was also revealed. The following conclusions can be drawn:
(1) The main phases of S0 were Al with Si and Mg2Si condensed around the cell boundaries. In contrast to S0, the contents of Si and Mg2Si in sample S2 increased. In addition, the Si that condensed around the subgrain boundaries was particle-like rather than fiber-like, as in sample S0. A new phase of nanoAl4C3 formed by the in situ reaction of Al and SiC. The byproduct Si produced by in situ reaction possess nanotwins. (2) The addition of nano-SiC particles changed the orientation of the samples. Because of the high cooling rate, a high stress existed, which led to local plastic deformation. The content of LAGBS increased. LAGBS evolved into HAGBS, resulting in significant grain refinement. Due to the hindrance of the precipitated phases, a balance between the LAGBS and HAGBS existed. In addition, a large number of nano-SiC particles also provided nucleation sites, which contributed to the grain refinement. (3) The nanohardness, tensile stress and elongation increased. The solid solution mechanism, grain refinement and particles around the cell boundaries such as Si, Mg2Si and hard nano-Al4C3 phase contributed to the increase in the stress. The dislocation networks formed around the cell boundaries, and the pinning effect of the precipitation stabilized the plastic flow, resulting in a high stain.

metadata.abstractText: AlSi7Mg is one of the most widely used aluminum alloys. However, its moderate strength limits its use as a structural material for critical parts. Most mechanisms used to strengthen the material sacrifice its ductility. In situ reactions during the selective laser melting (SLM) process rectify the trade-off by introducing dislocations around the subgrain boundaries and nano-twin planes in the by-product Si phase. This work was the first attempt to reinforce AlSi7Mg by nano-SiC particles fabricated by SLM. In addition, the rapid solidification rate caused solid solution strengthening, fine-grain strengthening and precipitation strengthening, which also contributed to the mechanical properties. © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
